content.description: Climb the Streak for 4 bolts then head right. Very dirty and chossy. Ignore the guide book this is a bad route that is not cleaning up.

A steep start on good, occasionally tricky holds through four bolts leads to easier breathing above. Next, a couple of intimidating bulges interspersed with a bit-less-than-vertical cobbles makes for an enjoyable, long journey upward.

A thought-provoking bit of climbing out of a scoop to the chains makes for an exciting finish.

There are midpoint anchors about 3/4 of the way up that you can use if you don't have a 70m rope. However, don't cheat yourself: go to the top anchors and use the midpoint anchors for lowering in two steps.
content.protection:
13 bolts, 2-bolt anchor in a vertical configuration with webbing.

There are midpoint anchors about 3/4 of the way up.
content.location: Right side of the wall, up the obvious black streak. First bolted line as you head upslope.

content.description: Two of the guides I had with me supplied conflicting information on this route (5.9+ vs. 5.10d).  It didn't take me long to figure out which was incorrect.  I was already tired from climbing all day and got so pumped that I lost count of my falls, and resorted to a french-free to make up for lost ground.  I ended up traversing to the arete to make it to the neighboring route's chains.  I'm sorry I can't provide more information than this for this route, but at least I can prevent aspiring 5.9 leaders from getting in way over their heads.  Scramble up the left side of the flake/boulder to the 2 belay chains.  Take the left bolt line.  Enjoy the dirty solution pockets!
content.location: Between the Engagement Alcove and Petroglyph Wall, a large flake/boulder sits just right of an arete.  The route starts on top of the boulder.  Rappel off the 2 chain anchor.

content.description:
A fun line with two cruxy sections and two decent rests. Good holds, bad holds, crimps, and pockets are all to be had.

Start up through some good, occasionally slopey holds to a bulgy bit where the big, obvious holds suddenly vanish. After a cranker move or two through the bulge briefly easier ground awaits.

Climb through the following almost-roofy bit onto more-or-less vertical rock for a while, until another bulge appears with a dearth of obvious holds.  Figure it out and balance your way to the chains while wondering if the pump will catch up to you before you get there.
content.location:
The line to the left of the obvious black streak (which contains

Streak

) at the right side of the wall.

The lowest first bolt on the wall makes it obvious.

content.description: My favorite climb at Maple Canyon (so far).  This route never lets up, and blesses you with nearly every Maple Canyon feature imaginable.  A variety of techniques and a whole lot of endurance will get you to the top of the arete.
content.location: Between the Engagement Alcove and Petroglyph Wall, a large flake/boulder sits to the right of an arete.  Climb straight up the arete.  Rappel off the chain anchors.

content.description: Head up the same start as Dry Ice. After the first 6 bolts just after the first roof/bulge, instead of veering left continue in the black streak straight up. This is a great route on excellent quality rock with distinct cruxes at the two bulges.

This starts on top of a boulder, so looking over your right side you are already 20 feet off the ground. This is an exciting 11, move right out into dissonance and climb crimp cruxes.  The exposure is amazing.
content.location: As you approach the wall look for the large boulder. Belay safely. There are 2 climbs on the boulder. Left to right: 11a, 11c. This one is the right one.

content.description:
A bit of an odd route in terms of the bolt line, but quite good nonetheless. This line shares its start with

Heathen

, .11b, which goes to the right of the black streak. The climbing is initially quite casual and then gets rather pumpy through a bulge, with just a bit of desperation showing through after clearing the bulge.

Start directly below the dark waterstreak that doesn't reach to the ground. Climb up through four bolts that initially trend slightly right and then back left to the bulge at the bottom of the streak.

After the fifth bolt, head up and left (rather than right, which would put you on

Heathen

, .11b). After two more bolts, head rather sharply left through another two bolts to end up on the chains for

The Emancipation of Dissonance

.
content.protection: 9 bolts, chain anchors (shared with the line to the left).
content.location:
Starts above a landing defined by the upper of two fence-post-and-lumber terraces; this line climbs up to a bulge that is at the bottom of a dark water streak. The easiest way to get there is to find the left-most bolted line in

The Pipeline

and then take the left of the two short trails directly across from that line.

content.description:
A long, very fun route that keeps getting more and more pumpy, right until the end. Mostly big holds, with a few small ones thrown in to keep you on your toes.

Start up trending slightly leftward for three bolts, and then head more-or-less straight up. The angle of the line changes a couple of times through gentle bulges, so take advantage of any rests you can finagle.

Near the end your forearms will be wanting big holds; alas, they might be a bit disappointed.
content.location:
Follows a faint waterstreak that doesn't reach the ground; this line is found about thirty feet to the left of the wide, dark waterstreak that defines the right end of

Pictograph Wall
